Sold only in a pack-in with the Sega Mega-CD, the collection added Super Monaco GP but was otherwise identical, including the version of Revenge of Shinobi included. In Europe the game was re-titled Sega Classics Arcade Collection Limited Edition.

Games:

* Columns
* Golden Axe
* Revenge of Shinobi
* Streets of Rage
* Super Monaco GP

Source: Wikipedia, Sega Classics Arcade Collection , available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77799.name: Rival Guide
77799.description:
Source: The Publisher Website.

The most dangerous foes in the world of the Pathfinder RPG are not always monsters. For the player characters are not the only magic-laden “heroes” with hopes and ambition to bring sword and spell into desolate dungeons and crime-ridden cities. This useful reference volume includes ten completely detailed parties of rival adventurers suitable for use as enemies, allies, or anything in between. Presented with a wide range of power-levels and diverse goals, the characters in this richly illustrated 64-page book also double as great on-the-spot pregenerated player characters.

77800.name: Bram Stoker's Dracula
77800.description:
In the game the player takes on the role of Jonathan Harker. Throughout the levels, Abraham Van Helsing will help Jonathan in his quest by providing advanced weapons. With the exception of the MS-DOS version, the game is of the side-scrolling genre. In the game, Jonathan Harker fights Lucy Westenra as a vampiress, Count Dracula's three brides, Dracula's coach driver, Dracula's fire-breathing dragon, Renfield and even Dracula himself and also in some different forms, such as him in his bat form, his young form and his evil wolf form. Levels in the game include the Romanian countryside, a rat-infested old village inn, Dracula's castle, Dracula's cavernous vaults, Dracula's misty catacombs, various locations in London, Lucy's crypt, a graveyard and Carfax Abbey.

Bram Stoker's Dracula is a video game released for the NES, SNES, Game Boy, Sega Master System, Mega Drive/Genesis, Sega CD, Sega Game Gear, MS-DOS and Amiga games consoles. Based on the 1992 movie of the same name, each version of the game was essentially identical (except for the Sega CD and MS-DOS versions). A CD-ROM version for the MS-DOS PC was released in 1995.

Source: Wikipedia, Bram Stoker's Dracula (video game), available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77801.name: Dungeons of Golarion
77801.description:
Source: The Publisher Website.

From the deadly heights of Gallowspire to the treacherous depths of the Darklands, Dungeons of Golarion presents a wide-ranging overview of six of the most dangerous delves in the Pathfinder world. With rough maps, adventure hooks, encounter charts, and notes on key enemies and treasures, this guidebook provides the framework for GMs to make these fantastic locations their own. Key sites highlighted in this 64-page volume include Gallowspire, home of the lich-king known as the Whispering Tyrant, Hollow Mountain, seat of a fallen Runelord, the legendary Red Redoubt of Karamoss outside Absalom, and more!

rpgitemversion: Guida Pratica alla Società dei Cercatori
77802.name: Pathfinder Society Field Guide
77802.description:
from The Publisher Website

This handy reference contains everything an adventuring agent of the Pathfinder Society needs to survive in the wild and wooly world of Golarion. From tips on information networks and secret orders within the Society itself to new equipment and ways to use your Pathfinder training to unlock special character abilities, the 64-page Pathfinder Society Field Guide is 100% legal for play in the international Pathfinder Society Organized Play shared world campaign, and is an invaluable reference for players and GMs alike!

77803.name: Vågspelet
77803.description: A sailing-themed roll and move trivia game with educational aspects and stylish components. Players answer trivia questions based on sailing when they land on spaces on the board. Players can choose to take on the role of "skipper" or "ordinary seaman" for variable difficulty.

videogame: Sega Genesis Classic Collection: Gold Edition
77804.name: Shining Force
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
videogamecompilation: Sega Genesis Classic Collection: Gold Edition
77804.description:
User Summary

This game was the first of the turn-based tactical RPGs in the Shining Force series. Players control their team of characters as they engage enemies on a grid-based battlefield. The characters have the ability to attack, cast a spell, use and item, or search the area. The units also gain experience by completing actions and defeating enemies. Each unit that the player controls is a named unit (non-generic) and has a class. The class can be altered or promoted after the character has gained the requisite amount of experience.

The plot of the game takes place in the Kingdom of Guardiana, in the land of Rune. The main protagonist that the player controls is named Max. Max is destined to defeat the main villain, Darksol. This will prevent his Runefaust minions from opening the portal that releases Dark Dragon. Max enlists the aid of allies to assist in his mission. These allies become the units that you control on the battlefield.

77805.name: Mickey Mania
77805.description:
Mickey Mania: The Timeless Adventures of Mickey Mouse is a video game released for the 16-bit Sega Mega Drive/Genesis, Sega CD, and Super NES. In the game, the player controls Mickey Mouse, who must navigate through various side-scrolling levels, each designed and based from classical Mickey Mouse cartoons from 1928 to 1990. The game was later released on PlayStation in Europe and Australia as Mickey's Wild Adventure.

This is also known as the first game that video game designer David Jaffe worked on.

Like many other games of its genre, the player must take on the role of Mickey and progress through each level, defeating enemies along the way and solving the occasional puzzle. Most enemies can be defeated either by stomping on them or tossing marbles at them. Frequently, the player must jump from platform to platform in order to advance, even occasionally within the constrains of a time limit (such as when escaping from a collapsing tower).

Source: Wikipedia, "Mickey Mania: The Timeless Adventures of Mickey Mouse," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77806.name: Atomic Bomberman
77806.description:
User Summary

This is an unusual entry in the long running and popular 'Bomberman' franchise, in that it does not have a single player mode (though you can play the standard multi-player game with the AI controlling the other characters). This release concentrates on multiplayer, with up to 8 players on a single PC, and up to 10 when playing over a network!

The gameplay follows the standard Bomberman style - drop a bomb, run away before it explodes. When setting bombs, the early aim is to blow up destructible portions of the arena, which would then drop power-ups. These range from giving you extra bombs, and larger explosions, to the ability to pick up bombs or to set off your bombs by remote control.

When you have built up a decent arsenal, your focus switches to trying to blow up your opponents. The last man standing on the level wins!

As well as powerups, sometimes 'diseases' are uncovered by your explosions. These include 'Short Fuse' where your bombs explode more quickly than normal, 'Molasses' where your bomberman is slowed to a crawl, and the highly frightening 'Diarrhoea' where you cannot stop dropping bombs! These diseases can be passed on to other players by touching them, providing an additional dimension to the game.

From the manual

For those of you not familiar with the Bomberman experience, I will spare you the details. The dynamics of the game are as easy as 1-2-3.

1. Drop a bomb.
2. Run like hell.
3. Watch your back (and your front, your left, etc. Just watch out.)

77807.name: Monsters (Probably) Stole My Princess
77807.description:
User Summary:

Monsters (probably) stole The Duke's princess! Each level pits you, an irreverent vampire, against a different monster in a tall vertical chamber with several platforms. To defeat the monster you must jump quickly from platform to platform, up the chamber. There is a strong emphasis on "combos", which are accumulated by touching as many platforms as possible exactly once. The higher your combo, the more points you get and the more extravagant your finishing attack on the monster.

Although the game has only a small number of levels, the game encourages you to play each level several times to maximize your score. There is also a challenge mode, outside of the main game.

77808.name: Star Wars: Rebellion
77808.description:
From the UK manual

Star Wars Supremacy™ is a grand strategy game in which you take the control of either the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance, managing resources, directing key characters, and assembling fleets from a master Command Centre. This game is set in the familiar Star Wars universe, and takes place shortly after the destruction of the original Death Star at Yavin.

Much of the action in Star Wars Supremacy takes place on a galactic level, you vie for control of systems, and use the resources form the systems you control to build up your forces, including your fleets.

When your fleets encounter those of your opponent over a system, Star Wars Supremacy turns from a grand strategy game to an exciting tactical one. In the tactical portion of the game, you exercise complete control over your fleets in battle, telling your capital ships and fighters which enemy ships to target and which manoeuvres and missions to perform.

To win Star Wars Supremacy, you must coordinate the resources at your command to fulfil the game's specific victory conditions: capturing or destroying your opponent's headquarters and capturing and holding your opponent's two top characters.

77809.name: 4x4 Off-Road Racing
77809.description:
User Summary

4x4 Off-Road Racing is an arcade style solo racing game.

Using one of four types of off-road vehicles (with fictional makes and manufacturers, but similar to actual vehicles), the player races against computer controlled vehicles. Money can be spent to customize the player's vehicle.

The four race courses in the game are described as follows: Baja (Rough Desert), Death Valley (Desert), Georgia (Mud & Hills), and Michigan (Winter). The player can choose from four levels of difficulty.

77810.name: The Three Towers
77810.description:
Middle age. War is coming to the city Pamplona. The growing tension between burgs had pushed them to build a defense. But there is not enough stone available to stand it. Be the first to build three towers and victory will be yours.

You have to build 3 towers each of them using 3 dices stacked and sorted from minor to major values. You can't repeat the same value in one tower.

Each player roll one dice in turn and tries to start new tower, stack the dice or pass. Stacked dice cannot be altered unless you roll a 6.

If a player gets a 6, he has these options:

* Roll again
* Finish and secure a tower. A tower finished in 6 can't be altered by any player (even himself)
* Swap his top stacked dices with other top stacked ones or with the newly rolled 6 (discard leftover dice)
* Blow up 1 top dice from enemies towers.
* 666: when a player gets a 6 three times followed (in the same turn or not) he destroys one enemy tower even if it is secured

The game ends when one player builds three towers. The other player has a last chance to roll a dice, but unless he gets a 6 he loses.

77811.name: Topic Bible Game
77811.description:
From a contemporary brochure from the publisher: "The object of the game is to form books of four cards each. The 60 cards in the game deal with 15 different Bible topics. For 3 or more players of all ages."

(Contrary to the publisher's brochure, there are in fact only 56 cards on 14 topics; the rules on the back of the box state the correct count.)

Game play is similar to Go Fish, but with additional luck and memory elements. Each card contains a topic, such as Patience or Forgiveness, and four relevant verses from the Bible. A player may keep a requested card if he or she can recite the requested verse from memory. If the defending player fails to recite the requested verse, the requesting player draws a random card from the defending player's hand, discarding it if it is not the requested card.

The winner is the player who collects the most complete sets of four cards with the same topic.

77812.name: Alone in the Dark (2008) (PS3/360)
77812.description:
Alone in the Dark, originally known as Alone in the Dark: Near Death Investigation and informally known as Alone in the Dark 5 to avoid naming confusion, is the fifth installment of the survival horror video game series under the same name created by Atari. Later, an upgraded edition with new scenes and gameplay elements, titled Alone in the Dark: Inferno, was released for PS3.

Source: Wikipedia, "Alone in the Dark (2008 video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.


Admin Note:

Alone in the Dark has been split into two entries. Differences:

Alone in the Dark (PC/PlayStation 3/Xbox 360) :


Developed by Eden Games
Similar plot, different levels


Alone in the Dark (PlayStation/Wii)


Developed by Hydravision Entertainment
Similar plot, different levels - removed all the freeroaming.

77813.name: Indiana Jones and his Desktop Adventures
77813.description:
User Summary

The first in the Desktop Adventures series, Indiana Jones is simple, top-down puzzle/adventure game designed to be played in a short period of time.

The player controls the title character, Indiana Jones, and moves through a randomly-generated world seeking items needed to solve the numerous puzzles and weapons to fight the various enemies and creatures inhabiting the world.

77814.name: Star Wars: Yoda Stories
77814.description:
User Summary

The second in the Desktop Adventures series, Yoda Stories is simple, top-down puzzle/adventure game designed to be played in a short period of time.

The player controls Luke Skywalker and moves through a randomly-generated world seeking items needed to solve the numerous puzzles and weapons to fight Imperial troopers and the various creatures inhabiting the world.

In the Star Wars timeline, this game takes place prior to the events of Return of the Jedi.

77815.name: Gradius
77815.description:
The Gradius games, first introduced in 1985, make up a series of scrolling shooter video games published by Konami for a variety of portable, console and arcade platforms. In many games in the series, the player controls a ship known as the Vic Viper.

Originally released as an arcade game, and later ported to other platforms. It is known to exist on the following platforms: NES/Famicom, MSX, PC Engine, Sega Saturn, PlayStation, Sharp X68000, certain mobile phones, and computer (Saturn, PlayStation and computer versions are all packaged with Gradius 2 as Gradius Deluxe Pack), as well as a re-release of the NES version for Virtual Console). The PC Engine version was also released on the PlayStation Network. In some territories, Gradius was released under the name Nemesis.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gradius," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame: A Collection of Activision Classic Games for the Atari 2600
77816.name: Boxing (Atari 2600)
videogamecompilation: A Collection of Activision Classic Games for the Atari 2600
77816.description:
From the catalog:

Put on your gloves! Here's your chance to go toe to toe with the Activision computer or a friend. Listen to the thud of those jabs and power punches. Keep bobbing and weaving -- but don't get pinned to the ropes! It's fast and furious action, but keep in training and you'll be a champion at Boxing by ACTIVISION.

From the back of the box:

Put on your gloves! You're about to mix it up in the most pulse-pounding fight of your life.

Listen to the THUD of those jabs and power punches. Watch your opponent reel back when you catch him with a good one. Keep bobbing and weaving -- and DON'T GET PINNED AGAINST THE ROPES.

It's fast and furious fun. And if you stay in training, you'll soon be a champion at Boxing by ACTIVISION.

77817.name: Def Jam: Fight for New York
videogamehonor: 2004 Game Critics Best Fighting Game of the Year Winner
2004 Spike Best Fighting Game of the Year Nominee
2005 D.I.C.E. Fighting Game of the Year Nominee
77817.description:
Def Jam: Fight for NY is the sequel to Def Jam Vendetta, a hip hop-influenced 3D fighting video game released for the GameCube, PlayStation 2 and Xbox and is followed by Def Jam: Icon. The game features several rappers, including Snoop Dogg, Method Man, Redman, Fat Joe, Ice-T, Xzibit, and Busta Rhymes, as well as the voices and likeness of other actors and celebrities, among them actors Omar Epps, Christopher Judge, Danny Trejo, Carmen Electra, and Kimora Lee Simmons. The game was spun off into a 2006 PlayStation Portable game called Def Jam Fight for NY: The Takeover.The game emphasizes strikes more, as well as proper use of the arena's environment and the surrounding crowd. Tossing the opponent against barriers gives fighters the opportunity to inflict massive damage to their opponent by tossing or slamming them into the wall headfirst, or using other features of the environment, such as slamming a door or gate in their face.

The crowd will shove a fighter back into combat if he is thrown into them or gets too close, and will sometimes hold a fighter, leaving them open to attack. Some spectators carry weapons, and will offer them to the fighters, or even attack a fighter if the guy next to them holds him.

Momentum is gained by successfully performing moves, countering, and taunting the opponent. The rate at which momentum is gained is effected by the fighter's Charisma, which is set for most fighters. Created fighters can set their own charisma with a combination of clothes, tattoos, and jewelry; the more expensive, the better. A fighter with a good set of clothes, extensive tattoos, or laden with jewellery can often fill their momentum meter in just a few moves.
When the momentum meter is full, a fighter can activate it, which results in a Blazin' Taunt. In this state, the fighter is said to be "Blazin", and can pull off a Blazin' Move, a powerful and brutal attack personalized for each character. A created character can learn every single Blazin' Move in the game, but can only have up to four usable at any one time.

With the focus taken from mixed martial arts, the only way to win a fight is through Knock Out or Submission. A character can be made to submit by putting them into submission holds until the health bar of a single body part is depleted.

Source: Wikipedia, Def Jam: Fight for NY , available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77818.name: Zombie Tycoon
77818.description:
Zombie Tycoon is a PlayStation Portable game that puts the player in charge of their very own undead horde. Contrary to most games who asks you to clear out a zombie menace, here you manage the zombies by using a mix of action and strategy. Created by Frima Studio, it was released for Halloween 2009 and uses the Vicious Engine.

Source: Wikipedia, Zombie Tycoon, available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77819.name: Gradius III
77819.description:
Gradius III (グラディウスIII 伝説から神話ヘ, lit. "Gradius III: From Legend to Myth") is a side-scrolling shooting game originally released for the arcades in Japan and Asia in 1989. It is the second sequel to the original Gradius for the arcades following Gradius II, and was followed by Gradius IV. Gradius III was later released for the Super Famicom in 1990 in Japan and for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System in North America in 1991. The arcade version was included with Gradius IV in a two-in-one compilation (Gradius III & IV) for the PlayStation 2 and in the Gradius Collection for the PlayStation Portable.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gradius III," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77820.name: Mount & Blade
77820.description:
Calradia is a land at war, a land offering great riches and even greater dangers to the adventurers and mercenaries that flock to shed their blood on its soil. With unerring courage and a strong sword, an unknown stranger can make a name as a warrior. Raise a band of hardened soldiers, become the lord of several towns and castles, and perhaps one day you may wield the power to depose kings and crown new ones at a whim.

Features:

Free-form sandbox gameplay. You are free to go anywhere and do anything you choose in a world that has more than a hundred unique locations, including villages, castles and towns.

Unique horseback combat. You are able to attack your enemies on your horse, whether you’re swinging a sword, holding a lance or unleashing arrows.

Highly advanced, sophisticated and intuitive sword-fighting system.

Fight on horseback and on foot using an expansive variety of medieval weapons, each with their own unique characteristics, strengths and weaknesses.

Be anything from a lonesome adventurer to a commander of armies or an owner of villages, castles or towns.

Freedom to interact with hundreds of characters, including kings, lords, ladies, commoners as well as heroes you can take on as companions, each with their own personality.

Source: The Publisher Website.

77821.name: Arsenal of Democracy
77821.description:
Arsenal of Democracy, or AoD, is a grand strategy wargame that is based on Hearts of Iron II and its Europa engine. It is developed by BL-Logic, a development studio made up by fans of the Hearts of Iron series and active members of the modding community. It was announced on September 8, 2009 and released on February 23, 2010.

As in other games in the grand strategy Hearts of Iron series, Arsenal of Democracy allows for the player take control of and manage nearly any World War Two and early Cold War era nation-state including its political, diplomatic, espionage, economic, military, and technological aspects.

Source: Wikipedia, "Arsenal of Democracy (video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77822.name: Chibi-Robo! Park Patrol
77822.description:
It is the sequel of the original Chibi-Robo! for the Nintendo GameCube. Unlike the previous game, Chibi-Robo! Park Patrol takes place almost entirely outdoors, and puts the player in the role of the titular character Chibi-Robo, a 4-inch tall robot tasked with revitalizing a park. The player does so by growing seeds into flowers by watering them with a squirter, and then spreading more seeds by causing the flowers to dance using a tiny boombox. The player can also alter the terrain, build and repair various structures, visit the accompanying town, and defend the park from noxious Smoglings, bits of pollution which can kill flowers.

Source: Wikipedia, "Chibi-Robo!: Park Patrol," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

77823.name: Okaeri! Chibi-Robo! Happy Richie Ōsōji!
77823.description:
The gameplay is similar to the original Chibi-Robo! in which the player takes control of the titular character, a 10-cm tall robot whose job is to clean the inside of a house to make his family happy. Chibi-Robo is owned by Jenny from the previous game, who is now all grown up and living with her son Keith and dog Lucky. The game introduces a tiny vacuum cleaner that Chibi-Robo can use to suck up dirt whilst connected to a power outlet and a tiny sifter used to find gems which can be turned in for money. The player can use the money to buy furniture for the house over a home shopping network using the telephone. The main difference from the original games in the series, is that instead of just having power outlets which let the player charge Chibi-Robo's battery, they need to put rubbish into a trash compactor to get electricity for the outlets.

Source: Wikipedia, Okaeri! Chibi-Robo! Happy Richie Dai Souji! , available under the CC-BY-SA License.
